executive_summary:
Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2024 currency.

The COVID-19 pandemic eliminated the need for many to seek nursery school care, leading to a significant drop in industry revenue. Government assistance through the CARES Act and the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) provided a lifeline to nursery schools, leading to a near-full recovery by 2021. As inflation surged in 2022, parents turned to cheaper nursery schools and alternate caregiving methods, straining prices and muting growth. Still, a rise in dual-income families and sustained government backing kept on a solid trend upward. Revenue has been climbing at a CAGR of 1.0% to an estimated $17.0 billion over the five years through 2024, including an expected 1.7% dip in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Tuition Rates Are Swelling as Nursery Schools Hit the Childcare Cliff
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Without ARPA funds, nursery schools needed to either cut staff and operating capacity or raise tuition. According to a Center for American Progress report, over half of all parents in the US live in a childcare "desert," meaning they lack access to licensed child care. This means they have few options and little power over available nursery schools, so most have been able to pass these down through tuition hikes.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Unemployment Trends Are Swinging Out of Nursery Schools' Favor
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: High interest rates are expected to push the US unemployment rate upward in 2024. Unemployed parents can watch their kids themselves, so nursery schools are a more discretionary expense for them. Unemployment is also increasing the number of family members, friends and neighbors available to care for children, making nursery schools' top substitute more viable. Revenue will accordingly sink in 2024.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Profit Is Sinking as Inflation Tempers Revenue Growth and Forces Nursery Schools to Raise Salaries
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Mounting inflation in 2022 also tempered revenue's prolonged recovery from COVID-19. As parents' essential purchases, like groceries and utilities, became more expensive, many switched to cheaper nursery schools or relied on family, friends or neighbors for childcare. Slowing revenue growth left many nursery schools less able to handle costs like rent and wages. Nursery schools have been forced to raise wages to retain caretakers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Government Funding Helped Offset COVID-19's Damages
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The onset of the COVID-19 pandemic wrecked nursery schools. The Coronavirus, Aid, Recovery and Economic Security (CARES) Act somewhat tempered losses for nursery schools, but revenue still nosedived in 2020. The rollout of the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) helped the industry bounce back from 2020's challenges. Nearly half the industry's revenue comes from government assistance plans.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Closures Will Perpetuate Accessibility Issues, Sparking Renewed Government Support
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As nursery schools contend with the end of federal funding, many can't raise wages high enough to attract caretakers and overcome the ongoing labor shortage. Nursery schools will continue to close as they struggle to offer competitive salaries. Federal allocations for nursery school assistance are expected to expand as legislators seek to address apparent issues in childcare accessibility and reduce the prevalence of childcare "deserts."

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Sinking Birth Rates Will Continue to Threaten Demand for Nursery Schools in the Long Term
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Birth rates have dropped over the last two decades and will continue doing so through the next period as adults choose to have fewer kids or none at all. With fewer kids born in the US, there will be fewer toddlers for nursery schools to care for. Competition may ramp up as nursery schools seek to improve their reputation to remain attractive to the shrinking number of parents.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Nursery Schools Will Somewhat Benefit From a Recovering Job Market
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the Federal Reserve begins to lower interest rates through the next period, businesses across many industries will undertake new investments and capital projects. Renewed investment activity will create new jobs, leading to an anticipated drop in unemployment in 2025 and 2026. More parents will be tied up at work instead of home, leaving them unable to care for their children on their own.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Growing Spending Power Will Expand Nursery Schools' Top Market
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The number of households earning more than $100,000 is set to climb alongside per capita disposable income as economic conditions improve through the end of 2029. These households generate nearly half the industry's revenue, so growth in the demographic will significantly benefit nursery schools. A rise in parents' spending power also gives nursery schools more control over prices.

industry_definition: This industry provides preschool education services and daycare for children aged three and four. Establishments in this industry are private, but they may receive funding from state and federal grants or charitable donations. This industry excludes babysitting or infant care services.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Government consumption and investment

key_trends: State regulations and funding impact local concentration
Parents have little influence over nursery schools
Federal support drove revenue in the wake of lockdowns
Elevated unemployment is straining revenue growth
High unemployment cuts demand for nursery care
Nursery schools in wealthier communities can pass down higher costs and preserve profit
Skilled caretakers are essential for a school's reputation
Nursery school distribution reflects population distribution
Universal prekindergarten policies can dampen the number of nursery schools in a region
Private programs make up over half the industry's revenue
Affluent families are the top market

market_segmentation.segment_description: Households with income above $100,000 can best afford the costs of daycare centers, including expensive centers that combine daycare with preschool instruction.

Families in this income bracket are less affluent but often working parents who can't care for their young children during the workday. Many parents' employers sponsor childcare, providing benefits that help them afford nursery care.

Families making under $40,000 rely on funded and nonprofit daycare centers. The Child Care and Development Fund (CCDF) and the Head Start program help low-income families find nursery care for their toddlers.

products_and_services.product_description: State governments fund many nursery schools, distributing subsidies to state-run facilities, private preschool programs and nonprofit organizations.
Privately funded nursery school programs are those operated by private individuals, organizations, or companies. Tuition fees paid by parents fund these programs.
The Head Start program mostly backs nursery and preschool programs that receive federal funding. These funds make nursery school accessible to children from low-income families.

tier_1_suppliers: Toy & Craft Supplies Wholesaling in the US
TV & Appliance Wholesaling in the US

tier_2_suppliers: Supermarkets & Grocery Stores in the US

Toy, Doll & Game Manufacturing in the US

Soap & Cleaning Compound Manufacturing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: State and federal sources fund an array of nursery school programs. An uptick in funding for Head Start, the Child Care Development Fund (CCDF) or Title 1 of the Every Student Succeeds Act directly boosts revenue for nursery schools, helping them provide services to more children.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Nursery schools that receive state funding (and even those that don't in some places) must meet certain regulations regarding teacher-to-student ratios, facility size, cleanliness, safety conditions, staff training, employee background checks, dietary programs and curricula. For example, California mandates a 1:12 teacher-to-student ratio for children aged four to six.

The Head Start program provides early childhood education, health, nutrition and parent involvement services but makes nursery schools subject to stringent federal regulations. Staff must possess at least an associate's degree in early childhood education or a related field, ensuring qualified educators. Programs must also provide nutritious meals and regularly undergo evaluations to ensure they meet specific educational outcomes.

Accreditation isn't required for private nursery schools, though many undergo the process to gain credibility with parents. The National Association for the Education of Young Children (NAEYC) and the National Association of Child Care Professionals (NACCP) offer accreditation if a nursery school meets rigorous standards for providing quality early childhood education and care.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Entrants need to meet state and local guidelines for staff-to-child ratios, facility size and cleanliness. New nursery schools that receive Child Care and Development Fund (CCDF) support or participate in the Head Start program are subject to heightened oversight.
Opening a nursery school requires minimum capital investment as most schools rent their establishments. Nursery schools don't rely on expensive infrastructure.

basis_points.basis_title: State regulations and funding impact local concentration
basis_points.basis_description: State-funded universal pre-K programs undermine enrollment in privately funded nursery schools.

Parents have little influence over nursery schools. Some reports estimate that over 50.0% of parents live in a childcare desert, so many nursery schools are free from intense competitive pressure. Nursery schools in densely populated areas are more subject to price- and quality-based competition.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Population Density and Location Preferences Perpetuate Fragmentation
concentration_points.concentration_description: Urbanization plays a significant role in market concentration. Cities with high population densities often see an influx of nursery schools since urban areas' large population translates to many children for nursery schools to care for. Parental location preferences also significantly impact concentration.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Income Distribution and Regulations Play a Role in Local Concentration
concentration_points.concentration_description: The state-by-state distribution of Pre-K funding and regulation significantly impacts the industry's concentration. Variations in the regulation frameworks and licensing prerequisites set up barriers to market entry, resulting in fewer schools and heightened concentration. A state's decision to implement universal pre-K programs can also impact market share concentration.

volatility_points.volatility_title: GOVERNMENT FUNDING HAS BEEN UNUSUALLY VOLATILE
volatility_points.volatility_description: The stability of nursery school revenue hinges heavily on government funding. With over 50% of schools relying on federal and state backing, even slight variations in government spending can cause sizable shifts.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: MODERN TECH HELPS NURSERY SCHOOLS IMPROVE CARE QUALITY
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Nursery schools incorporate technology (interactive whiteboards, educational apps, tablets and computers) to enhance the child's educational experience. Online technology allows more straightforward and more efficient communication with parents. Computer systems permit flexible scheduling options, which are increasing to include extended hours, part-time programs and drop-if care services to meet the needs of working parents.

FAQs.question: Have you changed your offerings to adapt to changing student interests?
FAQs.answer: Competition is high both internally and externally for nursery schools.

FAQs.question: As states have started putting tuition assistance plans into place, have you made changes to take advantage of this or combat this competition?
FAQs.answer: Some nursery schools can be funded both publicly and privately. These schools, as well as schools completely publicly funded, can take advantage of increased assistance.

FAQs.question: How has your establishment been affected by the socioeconomic dynamics in your area?
FAQs.answer: Higher-income families are most likely to pay for private nursery schools, while lower-income families are more likely to enroll in public nursery schools.

FAQs.question: Has your establishment considered expanding operations to include more satellite campuses?
FAQs.answer: By expanding to new locations, nursery schools can reach a wider consumer base. The industry's services aren't offered online, and parents typically look for the most conveniently located nursery school for their child or children.

FAQs.question: Have you increased your investment in educational technology?
FAQs.answer: As technology continues to play a more important role in consumers' everyday lives, parents are looking for nursery schools that offer up-to-date programs.

FAQs.question: Has uncertainty in some funding programs affected your investment strategy?
FAQs.answer: Total spending per student declined early in the period, making it more difficult for companies to spend on nonessential.

FAQs.question: How much do you rely on federal funding?
FAQs.answer: Over half of all nursery school funding comes from state and federal sources.

FAQs.question: Are you accredited by the National Association for the Education of Young Children (NAEYC)?
FAQs.answer: NAEYC accreditation criteria cover a wide range of quantitative and qualitative factors including, among other things, teacher qualifications and development, staffing ratios, health and safety and physical environment.

FAQs.question: How do your wage outlays compare to your competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Wages represent the highest cost for industry companies. Caring for children is exceptionally labor-intensive and can't be effectively automated.

FAQs.question: How do you deal with long gaps in the year with less funding?
FAQs.answer: Publicly funded nursery schools may look into private funding to supplement lower public funding.

FAQs.question: What proportion of your revenue is derived from donations and government funding? Are you taking full advantage of government subsidies and other grants? If not, how can you?
FAQs.answer: Federal and state governments provide various subsidies, including fee relief for low-income families. These subsidies promote demand for nursery.
